summary: This document is an email chain from May 2023 between FBI agents and attorneys from Hughes Hubbard & Reed and Patterson Belknap regarding the review of videos from the Epstein Estate. The attorneys report discovering a video that may contain child pornography during their court-ordered document review, prompting them to halt the review and seek guidance from the FBI. The emails coordinate meetings to discuss the findings.

persons.role: Email recipient (likely FBI or legal personnel)
persons.context: Copied on emails regarding the Epstein Estate video review and coordination of meetings with the FBI.

persons.context: Co-counsel at Hughes Hubbard involved in the Epstein Estate video review; referenced as someone who can provide firsthand account of the discovered video.

connections.description: Represent the two co-executors of the Epstein Estate and are collaborating on the document review and legal response.
Attorneys from different firms (Patterson Belknap and Hughes Hubbard) working together on the Epstein Estate matter; Ruzumna defers to McDonnell/Weiner for firsthand details.
Ruzumna reaches out to the FBI for guidance after a potential CSAM video is discovered; they coordinate meetings.
Coordinate in-person meetings at Hughes Hubbard's office to discuss the flagged videos from the Epstein Estate.
An individual, convicted of a child pornography-type offense, shared the suspect video with Epstein.

events.title: Initial Meeting Scheduled at Hughes Hubbard
events.description: A meeting was scheduled between FBI agents and attorneys from Hughes Hubbard & Reed to discuss the Epstein Estate video review.

events.title: Additional CSAM Videos Flagged
events.description: Hughes Hubbard attorneys inform the FBI that their review of Epstein Estate videos has flagged additional videos as potential child sexual abuse material (CSAM).

events.title: Discovery of Potential Child Pornography Video
events.description: During a court-ordered review of approximately 1,100 videos from Epstein's files, attorneys at Hughes Hubbard discovered a video that may contain child pornography, leading them to halt the review.

events.title: Court Order for Video Review Protocol
events.description: Judge Jed Rakoff signed an 'Order regarding Review of Videomaterials' establishing a protocol to protect reviewers examining Epstein's videos for document production.

locations: Hughes Hubbard & Reed LLP office (New York)
U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York
keyFacts: Attorneys reviewing videos from Jeffrey Epstein's estate as part of legal obligations discovered a video that may contain child pornography, shared with Epstein by a convicted individual.
The video review was governed by a court-ordered protocol signed by Judge Jed Rakoff to protect the reviewers.
Approximately 1,100 videos from Epstein's emails and files were under review for document production in connection with a settlement and SDNY litigation.
Upon discovering the suspect video, the attorneys immediately halted their review and contacted the FBI for guidance.
The emails show ongoing coordination in 2023 between the FBI and multiple law firms (Hughes Hubbard & Reed, Patterson Belknap) regarding the investigation into materials from the Epstein Estate.
